nodes.text: Whether retirement savings policies increase total wealth accumulation depends on whether they change behavior through active choice (price subsidies) or passive choice (automatic contributions/defaults)
Data: administrative panel from Denmark, 1995-2009, about 41 million person-year observations with third-party reports of employer and individual pension contributions and taxable account balances

Conceptual framework: two-type stylized model with active savers (optimize intertemporally and respond to price subsidies) and passive savers (set fixed pension contributions and respond to automatic contributions via reduced disposable income)

Identification strategy: combine firm-switch event studies (variation in employer contributions), an RD design for the 1998 Mandatory Savings Plan (MSP), and a DiD/threshold design around the 1999 capital-pension subsidy reduction

Automatic (employer) contributions: event-study and panel estimates show large pass-through of employer contribution increases to pensions and to total saving; a DKr 1 increase in employer contributions (holding total compensation fixed) raises total saving by about 0.78 DKr

Evidence from firm switches: pass-through of employer pension increases to total pension contributions ≈94.9% and to total saving ≈77.7% (estimates robust to controls, mass-layoﬀ subsample, and threshold estimators)

Mandated Savings Plan (MSP) RD evidence: MSP introduction (1998) increased mandated pension contributions and raised total saving near the eligibility cutoff; estimated pass-through of mandated contributions to total saving is high (roughly 0.85–1.02), implying automatic contributions increase total saving

Price subsidy (1999 top-bracket capital pension subsidy cut) evidence: individual capital pension contributions fell sharply for top-bracket earners; the aggregate reduction was driven by ~19% of prior contributors who mostly stopped contributing to capital pensions

Active vs passive prevalence: approximately 15% of individuals are active savers who respond to price subsidies (estimate from subsidy-change heterogeneity) and about 85% are passive savers who do not respond to price changes but are influenced by automatic contributions

Heterogeneity: active savers are more likely to be wealthier, older, and financially sophisticated (e.g., economics training) and change contributions more frequently; passive savers are less prepared for retirement and less responsive to subsidies

Persistence and long-run wealth: the increases in saving induced by automatic contributions persist for at least ten years and translate into substantially higher retirement wealth (example: switching to a firm with 5 percentage points higher employer contributions raised accrued wealth by ~25% of annual income by age 60 for a cohort)

Crowd-out from subsidies: when active savers reduced capital pension contributions after the 1999 subsidy cut, about 57% shifted to annuity pensions and nearly all of the remaining reduction in retirement contributions was replaced by increased taxable saving; estimated crowd-out implies roughly DKr 1 of subsidy produces ~0.01 DKr net new saving (95% CI upper bound ≈0.28 DKr)

Measurement and identification caveats: taxable saving measures are noisy (change in bank-reported assets), levels-based DD estimates are imprecise because year-to-year MPS varies; authors use MPS and threshold estimators, trimming, and permutation tests to improve precision and validate inference

Methods robustness: used threshold estimators (to handle corners), MPS-based IV, trimmed and median approximations, clustering by income bins or firm, and placebo/permutation tests to validate results

Conclusion: automatic contributions/defaults are substantially more effective than price subsidies at increasing total savings because subsidies induce relatively few responses, generate large within-retirement-account crowd-out among responders, and do not reach passive savers who are least prepared for retirement

Policy implication and research directions: policymakers seeking higher saving rates should emphasize automatic enrollment/default contributions; further normative and cross-country empirical work is needed to assess welfare and generalizability
